On october 11, 2012
[939518]

The problem with the armor in PVP is because the reduction of the damage is before the divide for PVP.
The formula is looks like this:
Assault is 100(+/-20%)
Defense is 50
Because assault is higher than defense it causes full damage which is 80-120
Here comes armor(lets say 10) reducing the damage to 70-110
And now it is divided by 10 for PVP so makes the damage between 7-11
Without armor of 10 it would be between 8-12

Before this new skill has been made, I told Epoq and the french admins to do something with armor(place the reduction at the end of the formula) but now it would be OP.
Just imagine a Bubble winks with armor of 12

On october 23, 2012
[884767]

Now that i've slept some, i can explain more clearly why the new are right on.
It is important for a game as old as DinoRpg to find ways to stay fresh and interresting.
Now, imagine a guy with a strong, team of a perfectly build Rocky, Dwink and Kabuki.
New updates are made, but each time he thinks: meh, my team is better. New races are available (mahamuti, Tofufu, Quetzu), but each time, he thinks: meh, my team is better.
This guy does nothing. No point in making new dinoz.
Now, with invocations, there is a chance this guy thought: oh, nice, Fujin. Mmm, maybe i'll roll one of them Clouds.

Now, with the new trees, there is a chance that this player thinks: mmm, maybe i should try a dinoz. And if you can get an old players with veteran dinoz to consider, even for an instant, about making a Gorilloz, there your update works.

Me, when i saw the new skills, i did look at dinoz element, check how doable an Uvavu Santaz would be. I also checked dinoz to calculate elements: Gorilloz, Maha, Tofu, etc. Yes, i took interrested in all those bad crappy dinoz. Maybe make a big giant 400 HP gorilloz that absorbs damage, steals life and shields his friends?
Bottom line is: these new powers make you consider new builds, new combos, etc... and that keeps the game fresh.

On november 4, 2012
[884767]

SOME FEEDBACK.

Ok, this feedback is a bit late, but i wanted to make sure i experienced leveling a few dinoz in the 50s to 60 before commenting.

Negative powers are a big failure. It's really sad, when we get new stuff, to find powers that are purely negative, like the old Awakening power.
Oh, there is a pay-off behind it you say? Well, that is the problem, we only have 10 levels. And now that i have leveled a few dinoz, i can tell you, even with career plan, this is not something easy to plan.

Take, for exemple, . The power Anaerobics. Now, this power is just a malus: -25% endurance.
Wait, maybe there is a treasure behind it, right?

Well, let's say you switched at 50, you get, in the best scenario (all ) Anaerobics at 53. Now, to get a "payoff", you need at least 2 more levels (unlock, then new powers). We are already talking about 50% air rolls in 10 levels. But then, the next powers are kinda bad too.

My point is, when we, as players, select a bad power, we gamble that we'll roll at least 2 more of the same element to get to the good stuff, and if we don't we just gimped our dinoz for nothing. No multi-dinoz will atempt this, they risk getting stuck on bad powers in 2 elements! And mono dinoz are bad enough that they don't need the malus.

Take another Exemple: Cleptomania. Looks nice in water uh? Well, you need 7 to get there. 70% water, that is some luck (or a Sirain). What is you don't make it. What is you get only 6 ?? Then you have faster resting (useless) +5 all assault (bah) + 10 armor (useless), +30 (good) and -10 initiative and -20% speed (terrible!!!), making your Dinoz a slowpoke guy that was stronger at 50...

So ya, bottom line: negative powers in the new tree = bad idea IMO.

LuxR

I'd love to hear the devs on the theory of the entire game .

Let's name some air skills that are so incredibly weak: Bubble, overload, vendetta, Fujin, Specialist, dodge, tornado, vaporous form, vacuum disk, Black Hole, ET. Your mix of sarcasm with constructive discussion doesn't make it easy to take what you have said at face value.

Your list of "incredibly weak" air skills are mainly double skills so that could be just as easily listed for their counterpart branch. Bubble was overpowered because it was available to a lot of races that didn't specialize in air and so could get a cheap skill without investing much.

Because air dinoz are slow, they don't get to actually use a lot of the skills you said, such as tornado (really low activate rate already). Blackhole is only powerful in the hands of non-air heavy dinoz who move fast enough to give a chance to spawn it... but only if the enemy isn't wearing high quality boxer shorts! It can't be used in IDT, CoTC, or PVE. Dodge and Vaporous form are decent, but serve to extend life at best.

The problem with air is that the dinoz who use it are SLOW. They have an entire chain (immaterial) that is irrelevant with one of the most common skills around (perception). Jump/levitator have very rare use (we'll see at the end of new chain whether this is still true) and poison, air's strongest skill, is negated by the ubiquitous and cheap poisonite, or SC/LB skills.

And so the ever plodding air dinoz master looks at the new skills in the expansion and says: I get to lose 25% of my endurance (no more casting invocations, that's for sure!) for some very mediocre skills? Yikes. There isn't a single known skill that begs to be gotten for air. And the further you have to go (such as needing 7 or 9 air levels up) makes it all the more unlikely to get there. Santaz rarely have CP and it is hard to get enough air on the other dinoz (cloudz/Kabuki/tofufu/pteroz) to actually have a shot at other than the terrible first set of skills.

Every other tree appears to have something useful. Lightning is questionable, but fire, water, and especially wood have plenty of good stuff to aim at that is realistic to get with 5 levels up. Not true for air.

I don't really have skin in the game, per se, as I don't have high level Santaz to worry about... but I just wonder why oh why they would take air's weakness (slow) and just make it worse and worse with the expansion when they aren't exactly taking over the game.

Well, one of my Dinoz acquired this junk ability. Here are my speculations on it's working based on my Dojo:
I believe the blue bar can contains 100 energy point. Most dinoz start with half a bar (max 50 points) but some abilities increase this.
When a dinoz uses Cramp, the opponent MAX energy is lowered by 10 until the end of the fight. So, he heals has usual, and does not loses it immediatly, but when he heals between fights, his max regeneration is lowered.

The casting dinoz gets -15% regeneration until the end of the match.

This skill needs to be turned off, because even if the -10 penalty is nice, the -15% is a lot worst, and if the Cramper dinoz casts twice, you can be sure he will be out of blue for the entire fight. I guess it could work on a dinoz without any A skills...

5 on 5.
Using No Mercy, my team gets one of the oppoenent dinoz (lets call him Rocky) lower then the rest.
My Castivorous Hoth gets Hypnoed.
Once on the opponent side, he triggers Shield Dinoz, thus protecting Rocky.
For 3 long assault, my No Mercy team tries to attack Rocky, and thus just attack my Castivorous.

On march 25, 2013
Loppermann

See the blue bar next to the yellow HP bar during a fight? That's endurance. It depletes when you do an attack (some A and E skills use high amounts of endurance). Your dinoz can't attack when it doesn't have sufficient endurance.

Zimbo

Do you have any clue of theory of probabilities? If you have an 80% chance for a multihit the chances for a 10times multihit are 0.8^10=0.107 which means 10.7% chance.

You have to multiply the probalities because the events are independent.

To clarifiy it even more, the chances for a 20 times multihit are 1.15% and for a 40times multihit they are 0.013%.

No offense, but if everybody is arguing against you, there must be something wrong with your theory

On march 27, 2013
Loxagon

I never made any statisticly relevant tests on double hit, but from purely playing this game for quite some time I got the following impression. "Double Hit" is a misleading expression. It should be "Multi Hit" instead. The rate for an additional hit to happen compared to several hits to happen is not that different, and surely not explainable by a 20% chance per additional hit.
I suppose that the chance to multi hit triggers something like 1-4 extra hits per trigger. That way longer chains are not as impossible as it seems by accounting multi hit chance for each single hit.
